result.query:
Please find the name of the catalyst and co-catalyst name from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
Please only generate the name of the catalyst and nothing else. Such as TiO2. ZrO2 or Ag, etc.
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
If there are multiple results, please indicate them as XXX-XXX.
catalyst: XXX
co_catalyst: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: the as-prepared ZBHx and ZBSx samples for photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 in cyclohexanol under UV light irradiation were tested.In this photocatalytic system, CF and CH were observed as the main products in liquid phase, which were detected by GC-MS in our previous work. 34Additionally, cyclohexyl ether and HCOOH were also detected.Control experiments showed that no expected products of CH and CF were observed in the absence of either illumination or photocatalyst, indicating that illumination and

that illumination and photocatalyst were necessary for this reaction.Also, neither CF nor CH could be observed by bubbling N 2 instead of CO 2 through the reactor or direct introducing CO 2 into the reaction setup in the absence of cyclohexanol under light irradiation.This indicated that cyclohexanol was not been oxidized under N 2 environment and CF was produced in the presence of CO 2 and cyclohexanol under UV light irradiation. Figure 7 exhibits the yields of CF and CH over ZBHx and ZBSx catalyzed

CH over ZBHx and ZBSx catalyzed reduction of CO 2 as a function of irradiation time under UV irradiation.As can be seen from Figures 7(a andb), the pristine BiOCl (ZBH0) shows a lower photocatalytic activity, while loading of ZnFe 2 O 4 nanoparticles on the surface of BiOCl significant improves the yields of CF and CH.The production yields of CF and CH gradually increase with the loading amount of ZnFe 2 O 4 increasing from 3 to 9 wt.However, further increase the ZnFe 2 O 4 content from 9 to 12 wt leads to

prevent catalyst sedimentation and a circulating water jacket was used to keep the temperature of the reactant solution at about 25 C.After specific irradiation period, the suspension was collected and centrifuged to remove the photocatalyst thoroughly.The concentration of the upper clear liquid was determined by an Agilent 7890A gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector and a HP Wax column.

photoluminescence spectra.The photocatalytic activities of the two different shapes of ZnFe 2 O 4 -BiOCl composites have been evaluated by photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 in cyclohexanol under UV light irradiation.The results showed that cyclohexanol was oxidized to cyclohexanone (CH), and CO 2 was reduced and then reacted with cyclohexanol to produce cyclohexyl formate (CF).The ZnFe 2 O 4 -BiOCl composites with different shapes showed much higher CF and CH yields than those of pristine BiOCl and

result.query:
Please find the category of Light_source and Lamp from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.
Please only select the generation from the provided possible choices.
Possible Choices:
Light_source: ['UV', 'Solar', 'UV-Vis', 'Monochromatic', 'Solar Simulator']
Lamp: ['Fluorescent', 'Mercury', 'Halogen', 'Mercury-Xenon', 'LED', 'Tungsten', 'Xenon', 'Tungsten-Halide', 'Solar Simulator']
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
Light_source: XXX
Lamp: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: 0.01 g of photocatalyst was uniformly dispersed in 10 mL of cyclohexanol.Prior to irradiation, high purity of CO 2 (99.995) gas was bubbled into the reactor for 0.5 h to remove dissolved oxygen and ensure the absorption and desorption of CO 2 reached equilibrium.Then, the reactor was sealed and illuminated by a 250 W high pressure mercury lamp. The intensity of incident light on the liquid surface was 3.2 mWcm 2 .During the reaction, the suspension was continuously stirred to prevent catalyst sedimentation

composition and chemical state of the samples were measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using a PHA-5400 photoelectron spectrometer with monochromatic Al K as the X-ray source.UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra of the prepared samples were conducted on a Shimadzu UV-2550 spectrophotometer using an integrating sphere attachment with a wavelength range of 200-800 nm.BaSO 4 was used as a reflectance standard.N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were examined on a Micromeritics Tristar 300

that illumination and photocatalyst were necessary for this reaction.Also, neither CF nor CH could be observed by bubbling N 2 instead of CO 2 through the reactor or direct introducing CO 2 into the reaction setup in the absence of cyclohexanol under light irradiation.This indicated that cyclohexanol was not been oxidized under N 2 environment and CF was produced in the presence of CO 2 and cyclohexanol under UV light irradiation. Figure 7 exhibits the yields of CF and CH over ZBHx and ZBSx catalyzed

on a Micromeritics Tristar 300 apparatus at the liquid-nitrogen temperature of 77 K, and the surface areas were determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra of the prepared samples were obtained on a Fluorolog3 fluorescence spectrophotometer with an excitation wavelength of 320 nm. The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with cyclohexanol was performed in a self-designed slurry reactor under ambient condition.In a typical experiment, 0.01 g of photocatalyst was

0.01 g of photocatalyst was uniformly dispersed in 10 mL of cyclohexanol.Prior to irradiation, high purity of CO 2 (99.995) gas was bubbled into the reactor for 0.5 h to remove dissolved oxygen and ensure the absorption and desorption of CO 2 reached equilibrium.Then, the reactor was sealed and illuminated by a 250 W high pressure mercury lamp. The intensity of incident light on the liquid surface was 3.2 mWcm 2 .During the reaction, the suspension was continuously stirred to prevent catalyst sedimentation

the as-prepared ZBHx and ZBSx samples for photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 in cyclohexanol under UV light irradiation were tested.In this photocatalytic system, CF and CH were observed as the main products in liquid phase, which were detected by GC-MS in our previous work. 34Additionally, cyclohexyl ether and HCOOH were also detected.Control experiments showed that no expected products of CH and CF were observed in the absence of either illumination or photocatalyst, indicating that illumination and

that illumination and photocatalyst were necessary for this reaction.Also, neither CF nor CH could be observed by bubbling N 2 instead of CO 2 through the reactor or direct introducing CO 2 into the reaction setup in the absence of cyclohexanol under light irradiation.This indicated that cyclohexanol was not been oxidized under N 2 environment and CF was produced in the presence of CO 2 and cyclohexanol under UV light irradiation. Figure 7 exhibits the yields of CF and CH over ZBHx and ZBSx catalyzed

on a Micromeritics Tristar 300 apparatus at the liquid-nitrogen temperature of 77 K, and the surface areas were determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method.
